subject: Re: [OT] HTML Parsing - was [junit] XML tree assertion
msgSnippet: ... HTMLParser does handle lots of dirty html, and its been built ground-up with a large suit of tests taken from real-world html. I started the project 2
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Ken Gentle <j.kenneth.gentle@a...> wrote:

> I recently came across a recommendation for "HTMLParser" from source
> forge. It looks promising, but I have not tested it. My next "spare time"
> project is to retrofit the parsing I mentioned above to use HTMLParser.

HTMLParser does handle lots of dirty html, and its been built ground-up with a large suit of tests taken from real-world html. I started the project 2 years back, as other parsers looked too complex to me at the time (most of them still do).

Right now, the HTMLParser project is entering an interesting phase. Together with Josh Kerievsky, we've been continuously refactoring and adding capabilities to do unit-testing of html and xml content - this helped us to unit-test xsl stylesheets.

For html testing, the parser treats html as dirty xml, and there is a method - assertXmlEquals() - this does the job of xml comparison - with the advantage of being able to comapre "dirty xml/html" - tags don't need to be closed. And yet, tag sets like
<td></td> and <td/> will be considered equivalent.

Ken, if you need any help in using the parser, feel free to post questions on the htmparser-user list.

Regards,
Somik

necessary to escape from a particular way of looking at a situation.

--- Edward De Bono in Lateral Thinking, Chapter 16, Analogies
